headline: New Ohio Senate Poll Shows More Bad News For JD Vance
author: Michael Ginsberg
sentences: Tony Fabrizio, a pollster who has been working for the pro-Vance Protect Ohio Values Super PAC, warned Monday that the “Hillbilly Elegy” author is perceived by many primary voters as too anti-Trump to gain their support.

The Club for Growth, which supports Mandel, has run an ad campaign highlighting Vance’s work as a contributor at CNN and opposition to then-candidate Donald Trump during the 2016 presidential election.
The two other candidates who have received major media attention, former state Republican Party Chairwoman Jane Timken and Vance, were in fourth and fifth with 6% and 5% support, respectively.
A Coefficient poll of 613 likely voters found businessman Mike Gibbons leading a crowd of six candidates with 20% support and former state treasurer Josh Mandel in second with 18% support.

(RELATED: Rep. Stefanik Endorses Jane Timken In Crowded Ohio Senate Race)
A spokesperson for Vance did not immediately respond to the Daily Caller’s request for comment.
A poll released Friday of likely voters in the Ohio Republican Senate primary race provided more bad news for venture capitalist and author JD Vance.

Coefficient has a B rating on FiveThirtyEight.
As I travel the state, I am hearing from hardworking Ohioans that they want a true America First conservative to represent them in Washington.
I am humbled that a growing number of Ohioans are putting their faith in me to be their next U.S. senator,” Gibbons told the Daily Caller.
A December poll by The Trafalgar Group found Mandel in first place with 21% support and Vance in second with 15% support.
“I am incredibly excited that our message of preserving the American dream is resonating with Ohio voters.
Vance has touted endorsements from Missouri Sen. Josh Hawley and Georgia Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene.
Rep. Tim Ryan, who is fundraising with the help of Hillary Clinton, is the likely Democratic nominee.

That poll was conducted just before Gibbons launched a $10 million ad campaign.
Gibbons, an investment banker, has loaned his campaign more than $11.4 million.
The poll, conducted from Feb. 6-8, had a margin of error of 3.9%.
